Let me give you an example. The US Tomahawk has a thousand pound warhead, a speed of about 500 miles an hour, and consistently hits within a few feet of the target. So America begins a war by blowing up air defense and communications systems with Tomahawks and then exploiting the opening to destroy the now weakened air defense systems. The Iranians use their missiles to blow up oil refineries and power substations and harass their enemies. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14985694
That information requires difference in measurements. This then entails that the amount of information a system can get from another system is determined by the ability of the receiver to discern between different states in the observed object. So, while "objective information," the maximal amount needed to describe a system might not increase, system to system information absolutely can increase as asymmetries result in more discernible states.

Information theoretic models of complexity never made sense to me before that. But they make sense when you realize that, in complex systems, more states are discernable from one another due to asymmetry.

Extremely ordered and extremely disordered states can both be models to high degrees of accuracy much more easily than complex states for this reason.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14984939
There's no such thing as wave function collapse. Prior to the scientist observing the cat, the cat is in a superposition of |alive> + |dead>. After observation, the scientist becomes entangled with the cat and the scientist/cat system is, relative to the perspective of an outsider, in a superposition of |cat is alive>|scientist sees cat is alive> + |cat is dead>|scientist sees cat is dead>. Quantum descriptions are all relative to the perspective you're talking about. If that third perspective observed the scientist/cat system, then he would become entangled and the system would be in a superposition relative to a 4th party.

Okay i'm going to try to take you seriously for a bit, your function:
[eqn] f(x) = \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i = x_1 + x_2 + x_3 + \dotsb + x_n [/eqn]
Does not have any [math] x [/math] term in it, so unless the [math] x_i [/math]'s are dependent on the value of [math] x [/math] then the derivative is just 0.
If they're indeed dependent on the value of [math] x [/math] and assuming [math] n [/math] is constant then you can just take the derivative of each term because the derivative is linear:

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
To build things at the nuclear level, you need a fusor. Fusors are expensive, delicate vacuum devices that require a lot of electrical power. There are ways around this but it either requires a nuclear fission reactor or a nuclear fusion reactor. The former is very expensive and the latter has yet to be built. That's your answer.

The problem you describe is not new. It's the gensis of all industrial chemical refining like a gas plant or a pesticide plant, with the big cracking tower/boiler being the place where products are broken down for assembly into others. Nuclear breeder reactors do the same on a nuclear level. Attempts to do exactly as you describe have been studied in the context of metallurgy and steel casting, but generally isn't done unless you can afford an expensive arc furnace which requires it's own power plant. Nuclear medicine works similar to what you describe as many chemotherapy treatments are made this way using research reactors.

The purpose is to review and lay out a plan for future inquiry pertaining to the modified cosmological model (MCM) and its overarching research program. "Two teams of scientists — one at Northeastern University, the other at the University of Cambridge — recently announced that they managed to manufacture, in a lab, a material that does not exist naturally."

We spoke to Laura Henderson Lewis, one of the professors on the Northeastern team, and she told us the material found in the meteorites is a combination of two based metals, nickel and iron, which were cooled over millions of years as meteoroids and asteroids tumbled through space. That process created a unique compound with a particular set of characteristics that make it ideal for use in the high-end permanent magnets that are an essential component of a vast range of advanced machines, from electric vehicles to space shuttle turbines.

The compound is called tetrataenite, and the fact that scientists have found a way to make it in a lab is a huge deal. If synthetic tetrataenite works in industrial applications, it could make green energy technologies significantly cheaper. It could also roil the market in rare earths, currently dominated by China.

But it will be a long time before tetrataenite is in a position to disrupt any existing markets, Laura Lewis says. She says there is still a lot of testing to be done to find out whether lab tetrataenite is as hardy and as useful as the outer space material. And even if it turns out to be as good, it will be five to eight years "pedal to the metal" before anyone could make permanent magnets.

threads.com: I fucking hate formal semantics. Literally just repackaged philosophy with no real world application whatsoever. Mental masturbation sold as "research". If semantics is a science then it lies at the extreme periphery of what reasonably can be.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14981507
Both the continental obsession with relativism and deconstruction, and stuff like sociolinguistics and critical theory, and the analytic obsession with formalism and rule-based descriptions of language are reductionistic positions. There are a lot of plausible arguments in favor of both positions, and if it's one thing we've learned from the history of science and philosophy, it's that opposing positions that both sound plausible and have a lot of supporting evidence are often not really opposed to each other, and can actually be integrated into a single theoretical framework that can account for the plausibility of both narratives. Consider for example, empiricism vs. rationalism, which were synthesized and integrated into a single theory by Kant. Consider the wave and corpuscular theories of particles which were synthesized and integrated by quantum mechanics. Consider Darwinian and Lamarckian evolution, the latter of which was discredited in the early 20th century, but which has since been integrated with Darwinian theory under the modern EvoDevo paradigm and the extended modern synthesis. Consider the nature/nurture debate (which is to some extent just a recapitulation of empiricism vs rationalism).
